title: The Epic of Shivaji: A Translation and Study of Kavindra Paramananda's Sivabharata
notes: The book was banned for allegedly containing derogatory references on grounds that it could cause a law and order problem.[52]

title: The Da Vinci Code
notes: The book was banned by the government for allegedly containing blasphemous remarks about Jesus.[53]

title: The Adivasi Will Not Dance
notes: On 11 August 2017, the government of Jharkhand banned The Adivasi Will Not Dance: Stories and summarily suspended the author from his job, on the grounds that the book portrayed Adivasi women and Santhal culture in a bad light.[68] The key complainants appear to have been the ruling party in Jharkhand, the Bharatiya Janata Party, the opposition party Jharkhand Mukti Morcha, and an academic at Jamia Millia Islamia.[69] The government's actions were widely criticised.[70][71][72][73] The ban on The Adivasi Will Not Dance: Stories was removed in December 2017[74][75] and Shekhar's suspension was removed and he was reinstated into his job in 2018.[76][77]

title: Teatro Political Dos
notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[193]

title: Shivaji: Hindu King in Islamic India
notes: In January 2004, a mob alleging disparaging remarks made about Shivaji attacked Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute where Laine had researched the book. Several rare manuscripts were destroyed in the process.[48] On 14 January, the state government run by the Congress Party under Sushil Kumar Shinde banned the book.[49] In 2007, the Bombay High Court revoked the ban.[50] The state government challenged the decision in the Supreme Court. Supreme Court upheld the previous decision and lifted the ban in 2010.[51]

title: Santsurya Tukaram and Loksakha Dnyaneshwar
notes: A Pune court ordered the copies of the books to be destroyed in June 2014. The complaint Jaisingh More had claimed that the book was derogatory to Tukaram and Dnyaneshwar. The publishers defended the book and the author's daughter stated that they will appeal in a higher court.[36]

title: Meendezhum Pandiyar Varalaru (Resurgence of Pandiyan History)
notes: The Tamil Nadu government banned this Tamil book on 30 May 2013 on grounds that it may cause violence and promote discord among communities. The book allegedly claims the Dalit community called Pallar, were among the rulers of the Pandya kingdom. The author has appealed in the Madras High Court against the ban.[66][67]

title: Jinnah: India, Partition, Independence
notes: Banned in Gujarat but overturned.[22] The book was on banned on 19 August 2009,[56] for containing defamatory references to Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.[57] Jaswant Singh was also expelled from his political party, BJP, for writing this book.[58] On 4 September, the Gujarat High Court revoked the ban.[56][59]Jharkhand

title: Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India
notes: The biographical book suggested that Gandhi was a bisexual.[60] It is banned in the state of Gujarat (where Gandhi was born) on 31 March 2011.[61] The Union Law Minister Veerappa Moily hinted that the Centre may also ban the book. Gandhi's grandsons, Tushar Gandhi,[62] Rajmohan Gandhi[63] and Gopalkrishna Gandhi,[64] expressed opposition to the ban proposal. On 4 April, Moily ruled out the ban.[65]

title: Dwikhandito
notes: The CPI(M) government banned the book on 28 November 2003 fearing that book could incite communal discord.[45] In November 2003, the Calcutta High Court put out an injunction against publication after a poet, Syed Hasmat Jalal, filed an 110 million INR defamation suit.[46] On 22 September 2005, the court lifted the ban.[47]

title: Who killed Gandhi
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28] The book was considered inflammatory and ill-researched.[22][23]

title: Tawid diwa sa pananagisag ni Bienvenido Lumbera: Ang Bayan, ang Nanunulat at ang Magasing Sagisag sa Imahinatibong Yugto ng Batas Militar 1975–1979
notes: Research on the literary works by Bienvenido Lumbera, who was imprisoned during the Martial Law period under President Ferdinand Marcos. Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government".[193]

title: Soft Target: How the Indian Intelligence Service Penetrated Canada
notes: The book claims that the Indian intelligence agencies penetrated the Canadian Sikh community, Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) and Canadian Security Intelligence Service (CSIS) to discredit the demand for a separate Sikh state.[34]

title: Smash and Grab: Annexation of Sikkim
notes: The book dealt with India's annexation of Sikkim. The Delhi High Court had stopped its publication after a political officer station in Gangtok at the time filed a defamation suit. The book was later allowed for release.[31][32]

title:
New Portuguese Letters
(Novas Cartas Portuguesas)
author_s: Maria Isabel Barreno, Maria Teresa Horta and Maria Velho da Costa
notes: Banned as "pornographic and an offense to public morals"; authors charged with "abuse of the freedom of the press" and "outrage to public decency"; uplifted after the Carnation Revolution in 1974.[196]

title: Nehru: A Political Biography
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28] The book purportedly contained grievous factual errors.[23]

title: Early Islam
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28] The book purportedly contained grievous factual errors.[23]

title: China's Foreign Relations Since 1949
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28]

title: The Jewel in the Lotus
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[21] Allen Edwardes was the pen-name of a scholar who wrote on Middle East and Oriental erotica.

title: The Heart of India
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[21] Alexander Campbell was Time magazine's New Delhi correspondent. The book is a fictionalized and humorous account of Indian bureaucracy and economic policies.[22]

title: The Evolution of the British Empire and Commonwealth from the American Revolution
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28]

title: Ramayana: A True Reading
notes: The Hindi version of the book, Sachchi Ramayana, was banned by the state government and all copies were seized in December 1969. The publisher challenged the decision in the Allahabad High Court. The court nullified the ban and asked the government to return all copies to the publisher. The state government challenged the High Court in the Supreme Court. On 16 September 1976, Supreme Court declared the ban to be illegal. However, the government ignored the court decisions and managed to stop sales of the book, until 1995. In 1995, after the political party Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) came to power, the book was widely published for the Periyar mela held in September 1995.[41]

title: Rama Retold
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[15] It was a play[19] which was a spoof of the Ramayana.[20] It was one of the first books to be banned in independent India.[19] The American edition was simply called The Ramayana.[20]

title: Pakistan-Pasmanzarwa Peshmanzar
notes: This book, originally in Urdu, cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Nine Hours to Rama
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[21] The book and the movie based on it, both were banned in India. The book was thought to be justifying the actions of Nathuram Godse who murdered Gandhi.[25] The book also points to the lapse in security.[14][22]

title: Nepal
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[21]

title: Marka-e-Somnath
author_s: Maulana Muhammad Sadiq Hussain Sahab Sadiq Siddiqui Sardanvi
notes: This book, originally in Urdu, is a Pakistani treatise on Somnath and it cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Man from Moscow
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28] Greville Wynne was a courier for the British Secret Intelligence Service (MI6). The book is about his involvement with Oleg Penkovsky.[29] The book was banned for purportedly misrepresenting Indian policies.[23]

title: Khaak aur Khoon
notes: This book, originally in Urdu, cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Dark Urge
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Chadramohini
notes: This book, originally in Urdu, cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Cease-Fire
notes: This book, originally in Urdu, cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: Bhupat Singh
notes: This book, originally in Gujarati, cannot be imported into India.[15]

title: An Area of Darkness
notes: Banned for its negative portrayal of India and its people.[22]

title: A Struggle between two lines over the question of How to Deal with U.S. Imperialism
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28]

title: The Scented Garden: Anthropology of the Sex Life in the Levant
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[15] This is a book about sexual practices and marriage rites of the people of Middle East (Levant).[16] The book was allegedly sexually explicit.[14]

title: The Land of the Lingam
notes: It cannot be imported into India.[6] The book is about Hinduism, caste and phallicism.[13]

title: The Face of Mother India
notes: It cannot be imported into India.[6] In 1927, Gandhi wrote a review of the book titled "Drain Inspector Report" which was published in the Young India.[12]

title: Satyarth Prakash
notes: Satyartha Prakash was banned in some princely states and in Sindh in 1944 and is still banned in Sindh.[38] In 2008 two Indian Muslims, Usman Ghani and Mohammad Khalil Khan of Sadar Bazar, Delhi, following the fatwa of Mufti Mukarram Ahmed, the Imam of Fatehpuri Masjid in Delhi, urged the Delhi High Court to ban Satyarth Prakash.[39] However, the court dismissed the petition and commented "A suit by Hindus against the Quran or by Muslims against Gita or Satyarth Prakash claiming relief... are in fact, meant to play mischief in the society."[40]

title: Rangila Rasul
author_s: Pandit M. A. Chamupati or Krishan Prashaad Prataab[1]
notes: In May 1924, this Urdu booklet was published in Lahore. The booklet purportedly described Prophet Muhammad's relationship with women. The publisher, Raj Pal,[2] was charged under 153A of the Indian Penal Code for hate speech by the Punjab government. The final disposition came in May 1927.[2] The court declared that law does not prohibit satirical writings about the deceased and the publisher was acquitted with a warning.[1][3] On 6 April 1929, the publisher was murdered.[3][4] The murderer, a Muslim youth named Ilm-ud-din, was sentenced to death and the sentenced was carried out on 31 October 1929.[5] Ilm-ud-din's defence lawyer was Muhammad Ali Jinnah.

title: Mysterious India
notes: The book cannot be imported into India.[6] The book purportedly contained stereotypes.[14]

title: On Fierce Wound – Fierce Herb
notes: Withdrawn from sales and destroyed after the decision of the Municipal Committee of the League of Communists of Kraljevo in Kraljevo, Yugoslavia in 1967.[289]

title: May Hadlang ang Umaga
notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[193]

title: Labas: Mga Palabas ng Sentro
notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government[193]

title: Kalatas: Mga Kuwentong Bayan at Kuwentong Buhay
notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[193]

title: The True Furqan
notes: Banned for purportedly mocking Islam.[22] The book has been allegedly written by a Christian evangelical group to proselytise Muslims.[23] The import of this book is strictly prohibited.[35]

title: Islam: A Concept of Political World Invasion
notes: The book was released in 2003. It was banned by the Congress government in 2007 ground that it contained derogatory remarks about Islam and Prophet Mohammad.[54] In 2010, Bombay High Court upheld the ban.[55] The decision was challenged in the Supreme Court but it rejected the appeal.[54]

title: Bhavsagar Granth
notes: Banned by Parkash Singh Badal-led Punjab government in 2001 for allegedly insulting the Sikh faith. The state arrested the people who were found in possession of the book, and confiscated its copies.[42] In November 2008, the Supreme Court of India overturned the ban, stating that the Punjab government was allowed to issue a fresh ban, if needed.[43] The Punjab Government then banned the book on 15 December 2008.[44]

title: A Modern Approach to Social Studies (2010)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[175]

title: You: An Introduction (2008)
notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[20] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

title: What Islam Is All About
notes: Banned in 2018 for "promoting enmity among different religious communities".[222][223][224]

title: Understanding Islam through Hadis
notes: The book, originally published in 1982, was banned for its critique of political Islam.[27]

title: The Satanic Verses
notes: Banned in 1989 for blasphemy against Islam.[28][221]

title: A Sneaking Suspicion (1995)
notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[20] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

title: What has Religion done for Mankind
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[15] This is a book published by the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society.[17] This book tries to refute Eastern religions.[18]

title: Ayesha
notes: This book is alleged to hurt Muslim sentiments. This book cannot be imported into India.[21] The original German title was Aischa: Mohammed's Lieblingfrau (Aischa: Mohammed's Favorite Wife).[26]

title: The Satanic Bible (1969)
notes: Banned during apartheid in South Africa from 1973 to 1993 for moral reasons.[229]

title: New World Translation
notes: In 2015, Russia banned import of the Jehovah's Witnesses' New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures.[201][202]

title: Angarey
notes: This collection of stories by Sajjad Zaheer, Ahmed Ali, Rashid Jahan and Mahmud-uz-Zafar was published in 1932. It drew protests from Muslim religious leaders.[11] In 1933, it was banned by the British colonial government.[9]

title: Rangila Rasul (1927)
notes: Currently banned in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.[27]

title: The Bible
notes: Spanish translations of the Bible were prohibited in Spain from the sixteenth until the nineteenth century.[235] In 1234, King James I of Aragon ordered the burning of Bibles in the vernacular.[236]

title: Fazail-e-Amaal
notes: Currently banned in Saudi Arabia.[218][219]

title: A Message to Man and Humanity
notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1967 for "false and wicked claims, and enemy propaganda that supports pro-Chinese politics".[289]

title: Unfree Speech: The Threat to Global Democracy and Why We Must Act, Now (2020)
notes: Censored due to inciting secession. Taken out of libraries because of the Hong Kong national security law.[103]

title: Moving Away from the Imperial Regime (2015)
notes: Banned. The book explores the unfulfilled promise of constitutional democracy, and another historian suggests that it may have been banned because the topic deals with the Chinese dynastic cycle.[101]

title: Mao: The Unknown Story (2005)
notes: Banned due to depicting Chairman Mao Zedong as a fascist leader against his people. Book reviews have also been banned.[84][85]

title: I Love My Mum (2004)
notes: A novella in which the relationship between Chinese citizens and their government are metaphorically portrayed as a cognitively impaired man in extreme sexual situations with their mother.[82]

title: China's Best Actor: Wen Jiabao (2010)
notes: Published in Hong Kong and banned in mainland China.[98] Author moved to the United States in 2012.[99]

title: Self Study Material on Nepal's Territory and Border (2020)
author_s: Ministry of Education, Science and Technology
notes: Banned for irredentist views regarding the country's neighbors.[175][failed verification]

title: Le roi prédateur (2012)
notes: Banned in Morocco. This book makes allegedly "defamatory" accusations of corruption against Mohammed VI of Morocco, after investigating the exponential growth of his wealth.[173][174]

title: The Tiananmen Papers (2001)
type: Compilation of selected Chinese official documents
notes: Controversy about this book include authenticity of selected documents and selection bias.[75]

title: The Price of Power: Kissinger and Nixon in the White House
notes: Briefly banned for alleging Morarji Desai to be a CIA informer.[22] The book claimed that Morarji Desai was paid US$20,000 per year, starting from the time of Lyndon B. Johnson. Desai obtained an injunction from the Bombay High Court for a temporary ban and sued for damages worth US$5 million in US.[30]

title: India Independent
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[28] It was banned for criticising the policies of the Indian government.[22]

title: Zhuan Falun (1993)
notes: Banned in mainland China.[67]

title: Year 501: The Conquest Continues (1993)
notes: Banned for distribution in South Korean military as one of 23 books banned on August 1, 2008.[233]

title: United States – Vietnam Relations, 1945–1967: A Study Prepared by the Department of Defense (1971)
author_s: Robert McNamara and the United States Department of Defense
notes: Also known as the Pentagon Papers. US President Nixon attempted to suspend publication of classified information. The restraint was lifted by the US Supreme Court in a 6–3 decision.[281] See also New York Times Co. v. United States.

title: Unarmed Victory
notes: The book dealt with the Sino-Indian War which India lost.[27]

title: The New Class: An Analysis of the Communist System (1957)
notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1957; author sentenced for enemy propaganda to seven years in prison, prolonged to 13 years in 1962.[289]

title: Captive Kashmir: Story of a Betrayed and Enslaved People
notes: This book is highly critical of India's stand on Kashmir. This book cannot be imported into India.[21]

title: Curved River
notes: In 1963 in Yugoslavia withdrawn by the publisher (Nolit) at request of SDB officials.[289]

title: Animal Farm (1945)
notes: Banned by government in 1948.[105]

title: Mein Kampf (1925)
notes: In Austria, the Verbotsgesetz 1947 prohibits the printing of the book. It is illegal to own[citation needed] or distribute existing copies.[26] Following the general prohibition of advocating the Nazi Party or its aims in § 3 and of re-founding Nazi organizations in § 1, § 3 d. of the Verbotsgesetz states: "Whoever publicly or before several people, in printed works, disseminated texts or illustrations requests, encourages or seeks to induce others to commit any of the acts prohibited under § 1 or § 3, especially if for this purpose he glorifies or advertises the aims of the Nazi Party, its institutions or its actions, provided that it does not constitute a more serious criminal offense, will be punished with imprisonment from five to ten years, or up to twenty years if the offender or his actions are especially dangerous."[26]

title: Mein Kampf (1925)
notes: In Germany, the copyright of the book was held by the State Government of Bavaria, and the Bavarian authorities prevented any reprinting from 1945 onward. This did not affect existing copies, which were available as vintage books. In 2016, following the expiration of the copyright, Mein Kampf was republished in Germany for the first time since 1945 as a commented edition by the Institut für Zeitgeschichte.[120]

title: Mein Kampf (1925)
notes: Banned during the regime of Jorge Ubico.[127]

title: Mein Kampf (1925)
notes: Banned until 1992.[122]

title: Mein Kampf (1925)
notes: Banned in the Russian Federation as extremist.[209]

title: Animal Farm
notes: Completed in 1943, Orwell found that no publisher would print the book, due to its criticism of the USSR, an important ally of Britain in the War.[210] Once published, the book was banned in the USSR and other communist countries.[211]

title: Animal Farm
notes: In 2002, the novel was banned in the schools of the United Arab Emirates, because it contained text or images that would go against Islamic values, most notably an anthropomorphic, talking pig as the leader of the farm. However, the ban is no longer enforced and has been recently lifted.[147]

title: Animal Farm
notes: Censored in Vietnam.[citation needed]

title: Snorri the Seal (1941)
notes: Satirical book banned during the German occupation of Norway.[184]

title: Howl (1955)
notes: Copies of the first edition seized by San Francisco Customs for obscenity in March 1957; after trial, obscenity charges were dismissed.[278]

title: Works
notes: Banned until 1954; published in Argentina.[244]

title: Vangar Gaan
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1924; ban withdrawn in 1949.

title: Proloy Shikha
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1930; ban withdrawn in 1948.

title: Bisher Bashi
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1924; ban withdrawn in 1945.

title: The White Disease (1937)
notes: Banned by government of Second Czechoslovak Republic in 1938.

title: Die Gesteinigten
notes: Banned and printed copies pulped[124]

title: Chandrabindu
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1931; ban withdrawn in 1945.

title: Thoughts of a Corpse
notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1983; republished in 2004.[288]

title: Castration of the Wind
notes: Written in Tuzla prison in 1984. Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1984; republished in 2005.[288]

title: Will the Boat Sink the Water (2004)
notes: Banned for exploring peasant protests. Sold an estimated 7 million pirated copies, despite being almost immediately banned by China's propaganda department.[83]

title: Things that Nullify One's Islaam
notes: Banned in 2018 for "promoting enmity among different religious communities".[222][223][224]

title: The Wisdom of Jihad
notes: Banned in 2018 for "promoting enmity among different religious communities".[222][223][224]

title: The Truth About Muhammad
notes: On December 20, 2006, the government of Pakistan announced a ban on Spencer's book, citing "objectionable material" as the cause.[189]

title: The Cover-up General
notes: Banned in the Netherlands by court order in 2015 as a former spy of Dutch military intelligence claimed she was described falsely in this Srebrenica book.[176] Ban lifted by the Court of Appeal of The Hague in 2016.[177][178]

title: Rebirth: Reformasi, Resistance, and Hope in New Malaysia
notes: Banned for containing insulting elements to the Malaysian Coat of Arms which is likely to be prejudicial to public order, security, national interest, alarm public opinion and contrary to any law, and therefore is "absolutely prohibited throughout Malaysia".[168]

title: Onward Muslim Soldiers
notes: On July 12, 2007, the government of Malaysia announced a ban on Spencer's book, citing "confusion and anxiety among the Muslims" as the cause.[165]

title: Lingren Wangshi (2005)
notes: The book, which documents the experiences of Peking Opera artists during the Anti-Rightist Campaign and the Cultural Revolution, was banned by the General Administration of Press and Publication in 2007.[86][87]

title: Gay is OK! A Christian Perspective(2013–2022)
notes: Banned for attempting to promote homosexual culture in Malaysia, which goes against religious and cultural sensitivities in the country.[169]In 2022, the ban was challenged through a judicial review petition in High Court of Kuala Lumpur. The court quashed the ban and ordered the Home Ministry of Malaysia to pay RM 5000 to the author.[170]

title: Bloody Myth: An Account of the Cultural Revolution Massacre of 1967 in Daoxian, Hunan (血的神话: 公元1967年湖南道县文革大屠杀纪实) (2012)
notes: An account of murders in a rural district of China during Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. Banned for 26 years and released in 2012.[100]

title: Big River, Big Sea — Untold Stories of 1949 (2009)
notes: It sold over 100,000 copies in Taiwan and 10,000 in Hong Kong in its first month of release, but discussion of her work was banned in mainland China following the book launch.[93]

title: Bad Samaritans: The Myth of Free Trade and the Secret History of Capitalism
notes: One of 23 books which from August 1, 2008, onward is banned for distribution within the South Korean military.[233]

title: The Great Replacement (2019)
notes: The Christchurch shooter's manifesto was banned shortly after it appeared on the internet in 2019.

title: The Peaceful Pill Handbook (2007)
notes: The book was initially restricted in Australia:[21] after review the 2007 edition was banned outright.[18][22][23]

title: The Peaceful Pill Handbook (2007)
notes: Initially banned in New Zealand by Office of Film & Literature Classification since it was deemed to be objectionable.[179] In May 2008 an edited version of the book was allowed for sale if sealed and an indication of the censorship classification was displayed.

title: Mao's Great Famine (2010)
notes: Banned for discussing the Great Chinese Famine.[96][97]

title: I Didn't Do It for You: How the World Betrayed a Small African Nation (2005)
notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of President Isaias Afewerki.[110][failed verification]

title: How the Red Sun Rose: The Origins and Development of the Yan'an Rectification Movement, 1930-1945 [zh] (2000)
notes: Banned for exploring in detail Mao Zedong in the Yan'an Rectification, and the internal struggles of the CCP.[71][72]

title: Capital and Ideology (2019)
notes: Banned for discussing China's income inequality and for refusing to accept censorship for a planned translation.[102]

title: Lethal Marriage
notes: Written by a newspaper reporter about the Paul Bernardo and Karla Homolka case, this book allegedly contains inaccuracies, additionally, complaints were received by the St. Catharines library board from the mother of a victim that led to the book being removed from all public library branches in the city.[50] As recently as 1999 this book was still unavailable to public library patrons in St. Catherines.[50]

title: Wild Swans: Three Daughters of China (1991)
notes: It talked about brutal political upheavals in China and purges of the Cultural Revolution.[62]

title: The Struggle Is My Life
notes: Banned in Apartheid South Africa until 1990.[230]

title: The Hoax of the Twentieth Century
notes: Classified as "hate literature" in Canada with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police destroying copies as recently as 1995.[50]

title: The Gulag Archipelago (1973)
notes: Banned in the Soviet Union because it went against the image the Soviet Government tried to project of itself and its policies.[214] However, it has been available in the former Soviet Union since at least the 1980s. In 2009, the Education Ministry of Russia added The Gulag Archipelago to the curriculum for high-school students.[215]

title: The Federal Mafia
notes: An injunction was issued by a US District Court in Nevada under 26 U.S.C. § 7408 against Irwin Schiff and associates Cynthia Neun and Lawrence Cohen against the sale of this book by those persons as the court found that the information it contains is fraudulent.[282]

title: The Conjugal Dictatorship of Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos
notes: Banned for during the Martial Law period due to being critical of the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos.[192]

title: My Secret Garden
notes: Banned in Ireland for its sexual content.[160]

title: How to Read Donald Duck
notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile. The Chilean army publicly burned copies of the book.[51]

title: Clandestine in Chile
notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile. On November 28, 1986, the Chilean customs authorities seized almost 15,000 copies of Clandestine in Chile, which were later burned by military authorities in Valparaíso.[53]

title: Apocalypse Culture
notes: Collection of articles, interviews, and documents that explore the various marginal aspects of culture. It was banned in Russia in July 2006 by court order for propaganda of drug use, owing to inclusion of David Woodard's essay "The Ketamine Necromance", after its first and only Russian publication by Ultra.Kultura (Ультра.Культура). All printed copies of that Russian edition were destroyed.

title: The Anarchist Cookbook
notes: Banned in Australia.[10][further explanation needed]

title: The Anarchist Cookbook
notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[266][267]

title: Suicide mode d'emploi (1982)
notes: This book, reviewing recipes for committing suicide, was the cause of a scandal in France in the 1980s, resulting in the enactment of a law prohibiting provocation to commit suicide and propaganda or advertisement of products, objects, or methods for committing suicide.[112] Subsequent reprints were thus illegal. The book was cited by name in the debates of the French National Assembly when examining the bill.[113]

title: Put 'Em Down. Take 'Em Out. Knife Fighting Techniques From Folsom Prison
notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[266][267]

title: Kill or Get Killed
notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[266][267]

title: How to make disposable silencers (1984)
notes: An example of a class of books banned in Australia that "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence".[17][18]

title: How to Kill (series)
notes: Banned in Canada in 1977.[48][49]

title: Naree (1992)
notes: Banned in Bangladesh in 1995,[29] though the ban was later lifted in 2000.[30]

title: The Lotus and the Robot
notes: This book contains the author's experiences in India and Japan. The book was highly critical of the cultures of both nations.[23] The book was banned for its negative portrayal of Gandhi.[24]

title: Why We Can't Wait
notes: Banned in South Africa because of its criticism of white supremacy.[228]

title: Twilight of World Capitalism
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: The Spanish Civil War
notes: Banned by censors of Francoist Spain for its negative depiction of the Nationalist Faction during the Civil War, and its critique of the Franco regime.[249]

title: The Social and State Structure of the USSR
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: The Second Sex
notes: Banned in Francoist Spain for its advocacy of feminism.[247]

title: The Devil's Discus
notes: Banned in Thailand in 2006 for violating the country's lese-majesté rules through its discussion of the murder of Thailand's king in 1946.[252][further explanation needed]

title: The Case for Communism
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: The Autobiography of Malcolm X
notes: Banned in South Africa because of its criticism of white supremacy.[228]

title: The A to Z of the Soviet Union
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Soul on Ice
notes: Banned in South Africa because of its criticism of white supremacy, and its sexual content.[228]

title: Concerning Marxism in Linguistics
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Black Power: The Politics of Liberation
author_s: Stokely Carmichael and Charles V. Hamilton
notes: Banned in South Africa because of its criticism of white supremacy.[228]

title: Aspects of China's Anti-Japanese Struggle
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Tombstone: The Great Chinese Famine, 1958-1962 [zh; fr] (2008)
notes: Published in Hong Kong, banned for discussing the Great Chinese Famine.[91][92]

title: Truth for Germany—The Question of Guilt for the Second World War
notes: In 1979 this book was listed by Germany's Federal Department for Media Harmful to Young Persons as material that could not be publicly advertised or given to young readers, due to the version it presented of the events that led to World War II. This restriction was lifted in 1994, after a long legal battle.

title: Pedagogy of the Oppressed
notes: Banned in Tucson, Arizona.[280]

title: The Work, Wealth and Happiness of Mankind
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[153]

title: The Tailor and Ansty
notes: Banned by the Irish censors for discussing sexuality in rural Ireland.[156]

title: The Spanish Labyrinth
notes: Banned in Francoist Spain because of its strong criticism of the Nationalist Faction's actions during the Spanish Civil War.[246]

title: The Outline of History
notes: Wells' book was banned in Nazi Germany.[116]

title: The Laws of Life
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education and Calendar-based contraceptive methods – even though The Laws of Life had been granted a Cum permissu superiorum endorsement by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Westminster.[155]

title: Problems of Leninism
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: On Cooperation
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Marxism and the National and Colonial Question
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Marriage and Morals
notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education, birth control and open marriages.[152]

title: Homage to Catalonia
notes: Banned in Francoist Spain for its support of the Republican faction during the Spanish Civil War.[242]

title: Commonsense and the Child
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for advocating sex education for adolescents.[152]

title: Combat Liberalism
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: A Short History of the World
notes: An expanded, Spanish-language translation of A Short History of the World, discussing recent world events, was banned by Spanish censors in 1940. This edition of A Short History was not published in Spain until 1963. In two 1948 reports, Spanish censors gave a list of objections to the books's publication. These were that the book "shows socialist inclinations, attacks the Catholic Church, gives a twisted interpretation of the Spanish Civil War and the Spanish National Movement, and contains 'tortuous concepts'."[240]

title: "Left-Wing" Communism: An Infantile Disorder
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Jugbani
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1922; ban withdrawn in 1947.

title: Durdiner Zatri
notes: Was banned by British authorities in 1926.

title: About a Silence in Literature
notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1951.[288][citation needed]

title: All Chinese literature
notes: Presidential Instruction No. 14/1967 (Inpress No. 14/1967) on Chinese Religion, Beliefs, and Traditions effectively banned any Chinese literature in Indonesia, including the prohibition of Chinese characters.

title: Buying a Fishing Rod for My Grandfather (2004)
notes: All of Gao Xingjian's works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[81][59]

title: Shanghai Baby (2001)
notes: Banned. Burned in the street and the publisher was shut down for three months because of its sexual and drug-related content, which has been accused of being "immoral" by the government. Other writers have accused the book of plagiarism.[73][74]

title: Uitgeverij Guggenheimer ("Guggenheimer Publishers") (1999)
notes: Banned in Belgium because this satirical novel offended fashion designer Ann Demeulemeester by making derogatory remarks about her personal looks and profession. A court decided the book was an insult to the individual's private life and ordered it to be removed from the stores.[41][42][43]

title: The Mask of Sanity (2017)
notes: Banned preemptively in Malaysia for blasphemy.[167]

title: The Man Who Wouldn't Stand Up (2012)
notes: Banned in Qatar in 2014 for its depiction of Islam.[198]

title: The Da Vinci Code
notes: Banned in September 2004 in Lebanon after Catholic leaders deemed it offensive to Christianity. (See Inaccuracies in The Da Vinci Code.)[122][164]

title: Serve the People! (2008)
notes: Banned for "slandering Mao Zedong", and depicting images of sex.[90]

title: Peichi (Tamil: ''பேய்ச்சி'')
notes: Banned for containing pornographic and immoral content.[171]Notably, it was the first Tamil language publication to be banned in the country.

title: One Spoon on This Earth
notes: Banned for distribution within the South Korean military for being "pro-North Korea".[233] It was one of 23 books banned there beginning in August 2008.[233][234]

title: One Man's Bible (1999)
notes: All of Gao Xingjian's works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[70][59]

title: No Game No Life (Volumes 1, 2, 9)
notes: Light novel volumes banned in Australia due to depiction which "in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a person who is, or appears to be, a child under 18".[24]

title: Love Comes Later (2014)
notes: Banned in Qatar.[199]

title: Into the River (2012)
notes: Banned in New Zealand in 2015; subsequently unrestricted in the same year.[180]

title: Interest
notes: Banned by the government of Indonesia for subversive and/or anti-government themes.

title: Goat Days
notes: Currently banned in Saudi Arabia.[216][217]

title: Fifty Shades Trilogy
notes: The entire trilogy was banned in Malaysia from 2015 for containing "sadistic" material and "threat to morality".[166]

title: Dream of Ding Village (2006)
notes: Banned for discussing AIDS in rural China (Plasma Economy),[88] the ban had reportedly been lifted.[89]

title: Candy (2003)
notes: Chinese government censored it because it was, "a poster child for spiritual pollution".[76]

title: 60 Years Later: Coming through the Rye
notes: An unauthorized sequel to J. D. Salinger's The Catcher in the Rye. Salinger succeeded in obtaining a court injunction which indefinitely banned the publication, advertising or distribution of the book in the United States, though it has been published in other countries.[citation needed]

title: Death Note (2003 – 2006)
notes: Officially banned, but discussion and pirated copies are allowed to circulate.[77][78]

title: Scouting for the Reaper (2014)
notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of civil liberties under President Isaias Afewerki.[110][failed verification]

title: The Boys
notes: Banned in Qatar in 2012.[197][further explanation needed]

title: Yellow Peril (1991)
notes: Banned. The book contains episodes of the collapse of Chinese communist rule.[63]

title: White Snow, Red Blood (1989)
notes: Banned in 1990, and both the author and publishers were imprisoned for publishing it. The book includes information about atrocities committed by the Red Army during the siege of Changchun, the smuggling of opium by senior Party leader Wang Zhen during the Chinese Civil War, and claims that China's official description of the "Lin Biao affair" is inaccurate.[60][61]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam. Salman received a fatwa for his alleged blasphemy[28]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[148]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[28]

title: The Satanic Verses
notes: This book cannot be imported into India.[33] Import ban was imposed after Muslim groups protested that it was blasphemous and hurt their religious sentiments.[22] India was the first country to ban this book.[23]

title: The Rape of Sita (1993)
notes: Banned for blasphemy against Hindu goddess.

title: The House of the Spirits
notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile.[52]

title: The Gods Laugh on Mondays (1995)
notes: Was banned in Iran after men torched its publication house.[149]

title: Soul Mountain (1989)
notes: Gao Xingjian won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Literature for the book, however all of his works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[58][59]

title: Sophie's Choice (1979)
notes: Banned in Lebanon for its positive depiction of Jews.[122]

title: Schindler's Ark (1982)
notes: Banned in Lebanon for its positive depiction of Jews.[122]

title: Paradise of the Blind
notes: Censored in Vietnam for criticism on the political party in control.[citation needed]

title: One Day of Life (1980)
notes: Banned by El Salvador for its portrayal of human rights violations.[109]

title: Lord Horror
notes: Banned in England in 1991 where it was found obscene; it is currently the last book to be banned in the UK. The judge ordered the remaining print run to be destroyed. The ban was lifted in the Appeal Court in July 1992 but the book remains out of print.[265]

title: Lajja (1993)
notes: Banned in Bangladesh,[31][32] and a few states of India. Other books by her were also banned in Bangladesh or in the Indian state of West Bengal. Amar Meyebela (My Girlhood, 2002), the first volume of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi government in 1999 for "reckless comments" against Islam and the prophet Mohammad.[33] Utal Hawa (Wild Wind), the second part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2002.[34] Ka (Speak up), the third part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi High Court in 2003. Under pressure from Indian Muslim activists, the book, which was published in West Bengal as Dwikhandita, was banned there also; some 3,000 copies were seized immediately.[35] The decision to ban the book was criticised by "a host of authors" in West Bengal,[36] but the ban was not lifted until 2005.[37][38] Sei Sob Ondhokar (Those Dark Days), the fourth part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2004.[39][40]

title: July's People (1981)
notes: Banned during the Apartheid-era in South Africa.[231] July's People is now included in the South African school curriculum.[232]

title: Burger's Daughter
notes: Banned in South Africa in July 1979 for going against the government's racial policies; the ban was reversed in October of the same year.[147]

title: American Psycho
notes: Sale and purchase was banned in the Australian State of Queensland. Now available in public libraries and for sale to people 18 years and older. Sale restricted to persons at least 18 years old in the other Australian states.[19]

title: A Feast for the Seaweeds (Walimah li A'ashab al-Bahr)
notes: Banned in Egypt and several other Arab states, and even resulted in a belated angry reaction from the clerics of Al-Azhar University upon reprinting in Egypt in the year 2000. The clerics issued a fatwa banning the novel, and accused Haidar of heresy and offending Islam. Al-Azhar University students staged huge protests against the novel, that eventually led to its confiscation.[106][107][108]

title: Happy New Year (1975)
notes: Banned in Brazil by the censorship during the military regime.[44]

title: Last Exit to Brooklyn
notes: Banned in Soho for frank depictions of taboo subjects, such as drug use, street violence, homosexuality, gender identity and domestic violence.[262]

title: "The Lottery" (1948)
notes: Banned in South Africa during Apartheid.[226]

title: Without a Stitch
notes: Sexually explicit. Ban never formally lifted.[186]

title: The World Is Full of Married Men (1968)
notes: Banned in Australia in 1968.[10]

title: The Stud (1969)
notes: Banned in Australia in 1969.[10][further explanation needed]

title: The Song of the Red Ruby
notes: Sexually explicit. Ban lifted 1958.[185]

title: The Naked and the Dead (1948)
notes: Banned in Canada in 1949 for "obscenity".[46]

title: The Lonely Girl (1962)
notes: Banned in Ireland in 1962 after Archbishop John Charles McQuaid complained personally to Justice Minister Charles Haughey that it "was particularly bad".[158]

title: The Fugitive (Perburuan) (1950)
notes: Banned in Indonesia in 1950, for containing "subversive" material, including an attempt to promote Marxist–Leninist thought and other Communist theories. As of 2006, the ban is still in effect.[147]

title: The First Circle (1968)
notes: After Nikita Khrushchev was removed from power in 1964, all extant and forthcoming works by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn were banned in the Soviet Union. This work details the lives of scientists forced to work in a Stalinist research center.[213]

title: The Dark
notes: Banned in Ireland for obscenity.[159]

title: The Country Girls
notes: Banned by Ireland's censorship board in 1960 for its explicit sexual content.[157][158]

title: Peyton Place (1956)
notes: Banned in Canada from 1956 to 1958.[47]

title: Përbindëshi (The Monster) (1965)
notes: Banned for 25 years in Albania.[3]

title: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich (1962)
notes: Banned from publication in the Soviet Union in 1964.[147]

title: Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949)
notes: Banned by the Soviet Union[122] in 1950, as Stalin understood that it was a satire based on his leadership. It was not until 1990 that the Soviet Union legalised the book and it was re-released after editing.[212]

title: Naked Lunch (1959)
notes: Banned by Boston courts in 1962 for obscenity, but that decision was reversed in 1966 by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.[279]

title: Memoirs of Hecate County (1946)
notes: Banned in the state of New York by the Supreme Court.[277]

title: Lolita (1955)
notes: Banned for being "obscene".[4]

title: Lolita (1955)
notes: Banned in Canada in 1958, though the ban was later lifted.[47]

title: Lolita (1955)
notes: French officials banned it for being "obscene".[4]

title: Lolita (1955)
notes: Banned for being "obscene"; uncensored in 1964.[4]

title: Lolita (1955)
notes: Banned for being "obscene".[4]

title: Lolita
notes: Banned for being "obscene".[4]

title: El Señor Presidente
notes: Banned in Guatemala because it went against the ruling political leaders.[128]

title: Doctor Zhivago
notes: Banned in the Soviet Union until 1988 for criticizing life in Russia after the Russian Revolution. When its author, Boris Pasternak, won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1958 he was forced to reject it under government pressure.[122]

title: Another Country
notes: Banned in Australia by the Commonwealth Customs Department in February 1963. The Literature Censorship Board described it as "continually smeared with indecent, offensive and dirty epithets and allusions," but recommended that the book remain available to "the serious minded student or reader." The ban was lifted in May 1966.[16]

title: A World of Strangers
notes: Banned in South Africa because of its criticism of Apartheid.[227]

title: The Hive
notes: Banned by censors of Francoist Spain.[248]

title: Hindu Heaven
notes: It cannot be brought into India.[6] Max Wylie, the creator The Flying Nun TV show, researched this book while teaching in Lahore.[7] The novel questioned the work of American missionaries in India.[8][9] It also dealt with the harsh effects of the climate on the missionaries.[10]

title: Berlin Garden of Erotic Delights
author_s: Erwin von Busse under the pseudonym "Granand"
notes: Banned for "indecency" by courts in Berlin and Leipzig[119]

title: You Can't Be Too Careful
notes: Banned in Francoist Spain for criticizing Christianity, and for mentioning the Bombing of Guernica by the Axis air forces.[245]

title: Ulysses (1922)
notes: Banned in the UK until 1936.[257][258]

title: Ulysses
notes: The complete 1945 Spanish-language translation of Ulysses was suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1962.[241]

title: Tropic of Cancer (1934)
notes: Banned in the US in the 1930s until the early 1960s, seized by US Customs for sexually explicit content and vulgarity. The rest of Miller's work was also banned by the US.[274] Also banned in South Africa until the late 1980s.[275]

title: Time, Forward!
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: The World of William Clissold
notes: Banned in Nazi Germany in 1936. A further note to the banning order added that "all other works by the author" were to be suppressed.[121]

title: The Well of Loneliness (1928)
notes: Banned in the UK in 1928 for its lesbian theme; republished in 1949.[259]

title: The Martyr
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[153]

title: The House of Gold
notes: The first book to be banned by the Irish Free State for alleged "indecency". Republished in 2013.[154]

title: The Grapes of Wrath (1939)
notes: Was temporarily banned in many places in the US. In the state of California in which it was partially set, it was banned for its alleged unflattering portrayal of residents of the area.[276]

title: The Bulpington of Blup
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[153]

title: Rowena Goes Too Far (1931)
notes: Banned in Australia because of customs belief that it "lacked sufficient claim to the literary to excuse the obscenity"[12]

title: Men of Good Will
notes: The English translations of Romains' novel sequence were banned in the Irish Free State.[152]

title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
notes: Banned from 1929 to 1965.[10][11]

title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
notes: Temporarily banned in the United Kingdom for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1960.[clarification needed][8]

title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
notes: Temporarily banned in the United States for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1959.[clarification needed][8]

title: How the Steel Was Tempered
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: Honourable Estate
notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[152]

title: História do Mundo para as Crianças (pt)
notes: The books was banned by the Portuguese government without any clear reason. According to the author, one possible reason was because he was from the "current of thought what claims that the discovery of Brazil happened 'by random'" or by the fact he "have registered the history of the 1600 years cut to the Arabian navy by Vasco da Gama".[195]

title: Forever Amber (1944)
notes: Banned by Australia in 1945 as "a collection of bawdiness, amounting to sex obsession."[13][14]

title: Forever Amber (1944)
notes: Banned in fourteen states in the US. Ban was lifted by an appeals court judge.[13][14]

title: For Whom The Bell Tolls
notes: Suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1968.[243]

title: Elmer Gantry
notes: Elmer Gantry was banned in the Irish Free State.[153]

title: Elmer Gantry
notes: Banned in Boston, Massachusetts, Kansas City, Missouri, Camden, New Jersey, and other US cities, this novel by Sinclair focused on religiosity and hypocrisy in the United States during the 1920s by depicting a preacher (the Reverend Dr. Elmer Gantry) as a protagonist who preferred easy money, alcohol, and "enticing young girls" to saving souls, while converting a traveling tent revival crusade into a profitable and permanent evangelical church and radio empire for his employers. Elmer Gantry also widely denounced from pulpits across the United States at the time of its initial publication. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[268][269][272][273]

title: Dutch Interior
notes: Banned in Ireland.[155]

title: Brave New World
notes: Banned in Australia from 1932 to 1937.[10]

title: Brave New World
notes: Banned in Ireland in 1932, allegedly because of references of sexual promiscuity.[151]

title: Boy
notes: Banned in 1934 after Hanley's publisher Boriswood lost a court case against a charge of obscenity.[260] Reprinted in 1992 by Penguin Books and André Deutsch.

title: And Quiet Flows the Don
notes: The English translations of Sholokhov's work were banned for "indecency".[152]

title: All Quiet on the Western Front
notes: Banned in Fascist Italy because of its antimilitarism (currently not banned).[161]

title: A Farewell to Arms
notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State.[152]

title: All Quiet on the Western Front
notes: Banned in Nazi Germany for being demoralizing and insulting to the Wehrmacht.[122][123]

title: A Farewell to Arms
notes: Banned in Fascist Italy for depicting the Italian Army's defeat at the Battle of Caporetto (currently this book is not banned).[162]

title: Storytellers II
notes: Withdrawn from print in Yugoslavia in 1964 because it contained stories by Dragiša Vasić.[289]

title: Grover's Eight Nights of Light
notes: Banned in 2017 for promoting Hanukkah.

title: The First Book of Africa
notes: Banned in South Africa for its celebration of Black African culture.[228]

title: The Story of Ferdinand
notes: Banned in Nazi Germany.[125]

title: The Story of Ferdinand
notes: Banned in Francoist Spain.[125]

title: Prisoner of the State (2009)
notes: Banned. The book is memoirs by former Chinese General Secretary Zhao Ziyang.[94][95]

title: Operation Dark Heart (2010) – oop
author_s: Army Reserve Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer
notes: In September 2010 the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) overrode the Army's January approval for publication. The DoD then purchased and destroyed all 9,500 first edition copies, citing concerns that it contained classified information which could damage national security. The publisher, St. Martin's Press,[283] in conjunction with the DoD created a second, redacted edition; which contains blacked out words, lines, paragraphs, and portions of the index.[284]

title: Zhou Enlai: The Last Perfect Revolutionary (2003 or 2008)
notes: Banned in China.[79][80]

title: The King Never Smiles (2006)
notes: Banned in Thailand for its criticism of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.[253]

title: My Father's Daughter (2005)
notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for political content.[110][failed verification]

title: My Watch (2005)
notes: Banned in Nigeria because this three-volume memoirs of the former Nigerian president were highly critical of nearly everyone in Nigerian politics. The books were ordered to be seized by the High Court in Nigeria until a libel case had been heard in court.[181]

title: The Private Life of Chairman Mao (1994)
notes: Banned for exploring Mao's private life.[68][69]

title: The Death of Lorca
notes: Banned briefly in Spain.[250]

title: Notre ami le roi (1993)
type: Biography of Hassan II of Morocco
notes: Banned in Morocco. This book is a biography of King Hassan and examines cases of torture, killing, and political imprisonment said to have been carried out by the Moroccan Government at his orders.[172]

title: Jinnah of Pakistan (1982)
notes: Banned in 1984 by the military dictator Zia-ul-Haq's government because of some 'offending passages'. Ban lifted in 1989 by the next democratic government.[188]

title: Spycatcher
notes: Banned in the UK 1985–1988 for revealing secrets. Wright was a former MI5 intelligence officer and his book was banned before it was even published in 1987.[263][264]

title: Life and Death in Shanghai (1986)
notes: It is about the author's personal tortured experience during the Cultural Revolution.[57]

title: The Untold Story of Imelda Marcos
notes: Banned in 1972, shortly after the start of the Martial Law period under President Ferdinand Marcos. The "unauthorized" biography was banned for the depiction of First Lady Imelda Marcos' extravagance.[192]

title: Ecstasy and Me
notes: Banned in Australia from 1967 until 1973.[10]

title: Borstal Boy
notes: Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958.[15]

title: Borstal Boy
notes: Banned in Ireland in 1958. The Irish Censorship of Publications Board was not obliged to reveal its reason but it is believed that it was rejected for its critique of Irish republicanism and the Catholic Church, and its depiction of adolescent sexuality.[15]

title: Borstal Boy
notes: Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958. It was allowed to be published in New Zealand in 1963.[15]

title: Old Soldier Sahib
notes: The book cannot be imported into India.[6] The book is a memoir of the author's time in British India as a veteran soldier.[9]

title: Friedrich Engels: A Biography
notes: Banned under the Internal Security (Prohibition of Publications) (Consolidation) Order.[220]

title: I Knock at the Door
notes: Banned in Ireland.[155]

title: By Grand Central Station I Sat Down and Wept
notes: Banned in Canada from 1945 to 1975 under the influence of Smart's family's political power due to its sexual documentation of Smart's affair with a married man.
